Package renderer.scene

Class Position

java.lang.Object
renderer.scene.Position
public final class Position extends Object
A Position data structure represents a group of geometric objects positioned (both location and orientation) in three-dimensional space as part of a Scene. A Position is a recursive data structure. Every Position object contains a List of nested Position objects. The list of nested Positions lets us define what are called hierarchical, or nested, scenes. These are scenes that are made up of groups of models and each group can be moved around in the scene as a single unit while the individual models in the group can also be moved around within the group.

A Position object holds references to a Model object, a Matrix object, and a List of Position objects. A Position's List of Position objects creates a tree data structure of Position objects. A Position's Model object represents a geometric shape in the Scene. The role of a Position's Matrix can be understood two ways. First, the Matrix determines the Model's location and orientation within the local coordinate system determined by the Position's parent Position (in the Scene's forest of Position objects). Second, the Matrix determines a new local coordinate system within which the Model (and all the nested models lower in the tree) is plotted. The two ways of understanding a Position's Matrix correspond to reading a matrix transformation expression 


                T * v
from either right-to-left or left-to-right.

When the renderer renders a Position object, the renderer traverses the tree of Positions rooted at the given Position. The renderer does a recursive, pre-order depth-first-traversal of the tree. As the renderer traverses the tree, it accumulates a "current-transformation-matrix" that multiplies each Position's Matrix along the path from the tree's root Position to wherever the traversal is in the tree (this is the "pre-order" step in the traversal). The ctm is the current model-to-view transformation Matrix. The first stage of the rendering pipeline, Model2World, multiplies every Vertex in a Model's vertex list by this ctm, which converts the coordinates in each Vertex from the model's own local coordinate system to the Camera's view coordinate system (which is "shared" by all the other models). Multiplication by the ctm has the effect of "placing" the model in view space at an appropriate location (using the translation part of the ctm) and in the appropriate orientation (using the rotation part of the ctm). Notice the difference between a Position's ctm and the Position's Matrix. At any specific node in the Scene's forest of Position nodes, the Position's Matrix places the Position's Model within the local coordinate system of the Position's parent Position. But the Position's ctm places the Position's Model within the Camera's view coordinate system.
